pros: They provide a decent salary for entry level. I had a very good experience with this company. All people are nice and professional. Knowing I was just a fresh graduate when I worked there, they believed my capabilities and supported me all throughout my journey. My team helped me build my confidence and thought me so much values that would make me mature and professional just like them. I'll missed the atmosphere and culture that might be difficult to find in other companies. As for the job, I was challenged and overwhelmed at first because I had to learn many systems and tools. But I get eventually used to it. Even I find it somehow routinary but I enjoyed working with the process. I thank this company for believing in me and the trust they bestowed in me.
cons: This company thrives in innovation. There's no way you should stay on what is permanent because they change everything in a short matter of time. Too bad when I already learned a process or work, I will pour my heart on that job and perform the best I can be on that process. Also, I am introvert and I prefer to keep everything as silo as it could be but I guess almost all corporation has this culture of collaboration and negotiation which I do not possess. I also felt the company values are not aligned with mine so I eventually get depressed and sad when I wake up everyday and not so excited to log in knowing my day will have so much meetings left and right. Not to mention extending my time because I had to meet our counterparts from different timezones so work-life balance is somehow compromised.

job_title: Talent Care Advisor/Recruiting Coordinator in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
Working at IBM was good. The problem was the client we provided services. 
Good benefits.
cons:
-Working for the TAO (Talent Acquisition Optimization). Last year, IBM and the client made the launch of a new recruitment methodology. These are the things that went terribly wrong: 
*They gave us poor onboarding, months after the office launch.
*There was a huge and constant escalation culture.
*Poor planning of the processes and procedures.
*They changed recruiters to this position (clear demotion) and helpdesk agents too (with no rise in payment, even though they were doing the same as recruiters). 
-Poor (or no) HR involvement in the situation.
-The talent care advisor position is just a call center appointment scheduling position. They sold us the position as a great growing opportunity.
- The majority of the team resigned to look for better opportunities. No one did anything about it. They just let us leave.

review_title: It is good but not one of the best places to work
pros:
*WFH
*Work life balance
*Annual salary increase most of the times
*Mandatory study plan of 40 hours every year 
*Sometimes there's budget for certifications
*Discount in transportation
*Asociación solidarista 5% retain
*Medical insurance, but just for you, not your relatives
cons:
*Very disorganized HR , services and employees evaluation. They put people you have never talked before to give qualifications of your job
*Employees receive exactly the minimum equipment necessary to do their job, which means laptop, charger, laptop lock, and headsets. Nothing else.
*Technology tools are old fashioned. Eg: Old dialing extensive phone numbers for every conference. Lotus notes tool is old and not user friendly.
*Parking is not under roof. Your car paint is burned under the sun 
*Opportunities to grow are very rare and given many times to friends of managers
*Favoritism from some managers is obvious and there's no mechanisms to detect it. Employees don't report that because they are afraid to be fired.
*Salary is below the market
*Payment is monthly and the date is confusing to employees. Calculating penultimate day every month is a formula hard to understand. 
*Benefits are very limited compared to other companies.

review_title: Sales driven culture with VERY little people focus
job_title: Associate Partner in New York, NY
pros: Large name with big name clients and deal sizes.
cons: The culture is overly focused on sales at the expenses of any problems that the consultants will have to fix later down the line. We were never encouraged to sell the right deal. We were encouraged to sell the deal at all costs. For example, my team had to deliver a 4 week consulting engagement. Before my team even touched the ground, the sales team had already spent a week doing "consulting" then asked us to provide the final deliverable in 3 weeks. In fact, they asked us to provide our recommendations the first week we landed. They did all this to win the deal and try to win larger deals but put my team under the gun. Additionally, I had a partner curse at me to center justify a paragraph versus left justify.

review_title: All comp based off base pay
job_title: Advisory Client Representative in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great benefits and training - IBM never really looks bad on your resume
cons: Pay - If you are a motivated and industrious hard worker, you are better off elsewhere. Socialized earnings - top and bottom not much difference. Better have a manager who will fight for your commissions. I continually blew out my quota but was given retroactive quota increases - that resulted in negative commission checks! Yes - I am being serious. Explanation: "Since you do so well and were paid in the bonus in the previous quarter, with the increased quota, you were actually overpaid ... so you owe us money." They never made you pay it and tried to make it sound like you were being done a favor when it was 'wiped clean' at the beginning of the next year. Net net - they fund you not off the dollars you sell but at a percentage of your salary. Go someplace that pays you for what you actually sell at a guaranteed rate.

- certain development practices are severely undervalued
- no 401k match until 2 years of service

pros: Big company benefits, plenty of room to move up.
cons:
Working for (some particular branches of) GBS means you'll never maintain the same tech on your resume. This made it somewhat rough finding another job. You will need to be adamant in communicating that you want to be on similar projects. If you're starting, try to choose a popular tech stack and stick with it. 

The branch I was in was definitely top heavy, promoting individuals that weren't particularly ready in my opinion.

While there is plenty of room to move up, the raises are slow going but I am very satisfied as a junior dev to mid working there.

Remember GBS does not reflect all of IBM!

review_title: Good place to start, bad place to keep growing
job_title: Product Designer in San Jose, CA
pros: The company is massive and you have a lot of opportunities to reinvent yourself by changing roles or projects. There is a network for just about anything you're interested in doing professionally or otherwise, and you meet a lot of smart and interesting people around the world. Because there is a lot of redundancy and the timescales for product development are longer than average, there is a lot of room to fail, which is great if you're starting out in the industry.
cons: Culture is hugely dependent on which business unit your role falls under and your job function. There's zero transparency on job cuts (which they harshly refer to as "resource actions"), yet these happen nearly every year and affect most areas of the business. Most actions you'd want to take on your career/goals are mired in bureaucracy, and if you have a manager who is less experienced, they are stymied in their efforts to promote you or even give you an annual salary increase.

review_title: It's a bittersweet experience working at IBM Research
job_title: Advisory Research Engineer in New Delhi
pros:
- Freedom to pursue your interests 
- Work life balance is great
- Senior management and folks in high positions are accessible
cons:
- Hard to climb the corporate ladder, have to constantly please senior management and be in their good books
- Skills/work done/impact only matter if management is onboard. In short mediocre work aligned to business is highly rewarded than cutting edge research.
- Collaboration on the face of it but competition through and through. As researchers you would expect a collaborative environment to progress but usually credit is given to one person who is favoured by management. In short equal contribution isn't valued, the lead gets all the credit. 
- You would be surrounded with people who don't do any work, are content, yet earn the same or even more than you which is highly demotivating. 
- Incompetent senior management. Although company vision and focus areas are top driven, the entire meat of the work is expected to be shouldered by the bottom level employees. You are expected to come up with ideas, define agendas, find usecases, make connects through meetings, write code and deliver on individual threads, do external collaboration, sell your work in the community, publish your work in A+ conferences etc.
- Salary is average compared to similar roles/experience in other companies in India.

review_title: Design at IBM is fast, but IBM is slow
job_title: User Experience Designer in San Jose, CA
pros: The people who work in the design org at IBM are very supportive, whether it's a fellow teammate or a manager. I feel like I can ask anyone a question and get what I need to do well. The design studio is a very collaborative and fun environment.
cons: Design at IBM is quite young. As a result, not all of the teams at the company really know what to do with designers. We try to advocate for being involved in the entire product development process, but we're sometimes brought in at the last minute or the time our work takes to do is de-prioritized. Across most of the company, there isn't a very strong process in place, and it's hard for design to truly, seamlessly collaborate with our partners in Dev and Project Management. Which can be frustrating.

review_title: Great work life balance, decent pay, methodology laggard
job_title: Advisory Circuit Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
Generous and flexible vacation and parental leave. While the pay is less than most silicon valley tech giants, I feel it is competitive and fair, especially considering the workload for an employee that "meets expectations".

For someone that is a go-getter, it is not a hard place to impress management, build a network internal to IBM, move around to new roles that better suit your interests, and generally excel. There is also a culture of acceptance that there are people who "just do their job" for their entire career, and while this seems like a negative thing, I think this balance of proactives and stagnants creates for a harmonious work environment unlike the vicious/toxic environments that are so present at many other highly competitive tech companies.
cons:
IBM loves to build tools in house, while they have recently started to branch out, there is always "a tool that IBM owns" that was written back in the stone age that is free and they force their employees to "make it work". In some cases management finally broke down and moved to industry standard software, but in most cases not.

IBM is also so old, there's a "way things have always been done" and changing that is near impossible. Then the big changes that management starts from top down, the old world employees don't fully adopt or don't understand, making any real progress very painful.

review_title: Good Old School Legacy Company to Start/getting Retired - Lack Modernization, Guidance , Incapable Lower Management
pros:
1) You will get a lot of training Opportunities, training materials.
2) You will get opportunity to a lot of certifications - entire Company is behind certifying the employees in something (Does not matter if his/her job needs that or not)
3) Ample amount of projects.
4) You can be a star performing resource only in IBM by doing nothing other than Doing any meaningless Certifications, Having a good personal relations with many colleagues while staying in the Company for 20+ years, by providing bootcamp/any training to the people and wasting your time preparing for the training.
5) If you can hold your breath for 10 to 20 years in IBM - you will get opportunity to settle down abroad and will become a manager (Band Growth will still be a question though after Band 8 or 9).
6) Opportunities take time to come to you mostly, unless you are lucky, but, you will get for sure if you stay and keep doing what you do daily for the next 5 to 10 years at least.
cons:
1) Very less growth opportunity.
2) Oversees Opportunities are very less.
3) Poor Technology Architect team/Bad futuristic planning/Design.
4) Lack modernization, should have worked more closely with AWS/Azure/GCP than investing so much on the IBM cloud (Still feels like legacy).
5) Lower People management folks are not good (don't know about all other projects). And most of them have survived 10+ years in IBM to become an IBM Manager. They have forgotten even how to behave with the new senior resources.
6) Recommending something, and asking support to the management - is backfiring. You will get only blame in return than support. He will make you fee - how easy it was and how you have messed it up - even if that's tough. Lack of real experience.
7) Modernization is happening - but the strategy is not good. First change the old school lower management - when you are bringing new resources under them. The lower management folks are 10 to 20 years sitting on the same position and role and frustrated - how could you expect the new skilled experienced higher paid resources will be treated well?
8) Switching a project is tough - if you are performing very well. That's different that no one appreciate you for that unless you share that you want to leave.
9) Using your technical skills/your certified technology's skills are very minimum. Everyone is doing certification on the technologies in reality - that has nothing to do with their daily job.
10) IBM works on theory than Reality.
11) We were once the most advanced futuristic company. But, now those days are history.
12) If you are really looking for growth - then trust me - if you are staying in IBM for more than 1.5 years just for any future Oversees opportunity, you will destroy your career and will go into the depression.
13) Corporate politics is everywhere - an that depends on the people how they become the part of it or the victim of it, depends on how smart and open you are. But, it's there.
14) Hiring is not transparent. If the technical panel is rejecting a profile, manager still hires him as he/she is coming via someone close's recommendation. Me/my colleagues are already facing it before leaving the show off panel.
15) Please don't join the SRE team ever. Trust me - IBM is an Old school company, they really dont know the meaning of the SRE yet or their roles.

review_title: My first two years as IBMer
pros:
When I was newcomer I had a lot of fears about how I will be able to integrate myself into the team and the larger IBM, then I shortly realized that it is easier than I thought. I have a lot of very talented and friendly colleagues and excellent skilled managers. I had the opportunity to learn, not only things strictly related to my actual job role, but with a larger view into the IBM processes and priorities. I have the chance to show my talent by being an active member of the Talent Program, Social Team, certified internal trainer and by participating in a lot of internal projects. In my first year I achieved the Super Learner status, in the second year the Champion Learner Gold, earning a total of 10 badges.
Of course, there is still so much to learn! I have great plans for 2021. I would like to learn management skills, virtual training and other interesting and useful knowledge.
cons: I couldn't say any downside of working at IBM. This is a very inclusive, modern company with a bright future. I really hope that this will remain and even develop in the future.

pros: Flexible with work from home, relatively high pay (but low for big tech), some in demand skills and experiences.
cons: Limited exposure to work with clients, dysfunctional sales methodology. Product roadmaps were very unstable and often rebranded and shifted products in a way that left clients unsure of what they were buying. Many of the software products are created and not maintained, either from FAQs all the way to functionality issues. Also the company really isn't ready to sell in a cloud based world, there are still a lot of perpetual licenses and the company really struggles with selling usage based products like AWS.

pros: Consider IaaS as the foundation to future-proof your business. IaaS solutions are designed to be highly scalable and flexible, meaning you can buy additional resources and features you need as your operations expand. Compare this to having to buy more physical hardware and hiring more IT professionals for maintenance as your business grows and you require more storage and servers.
cons: One good analogy for IaaS is that of a leased car. Say you are in the delivery service and business booms. You don’t need to buy a new delivery vehicle but simply lease another car to keep up with the growing requirements of your business. As demand continuously goes into an upswing, you just lease another vehicle and so on until the economic equation justifies investment in a new car. Buy a new car at the onset then suddenly business drops and you end up with an unwarranted expense.

review_title: A good place to work in for a few years
job_title: Software Development Engineer In Test (SDET) in Dublin, Dublin
pros: There is a competitive starting salary for graduates, there are lots of very experienced engineers you get to work within the company. There are lots of opportunities to change teams, products or job roles. There’s time allocated to all employees for self-learning (Learning new technical skills, online courses etc..), the company looks impressive on a CV
cons: Salary stays pretty static, teams working on different components in the same product are a bit isolated from others and this can cause problems when one team makes a change that breaks another teams component without notifying them of the change. Knowledge sharing between team members could be a lot better, there is a high chance of working on a product for two or three years that gets cancelled. Coffee/food/snakes you have to pay for. There’s also a very poor concept of working overtime, you will get your time back in lieu but not cash may not be an option. There’s also a bit of a disconnect from very senior management and regular staff.

Job Stability

review_title: *WARNING LOCALS AND NONLOCALS* DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME AT ROCKET CENTER
pros: You can get certs and free training for certs that about the only pro about rocket center
cons: I have never worked for a company to exploit its employees like this one does. 80hr weeks, the min is "44" and you get paid for 40 hrs. Zero compensation. Rocket Center Management is so out of touch with reality, they hire from outside of the area and those employees leave and they think its because they are not from here.... they leave because you MIGHT make 45k so they are targeting locals to exploit because they think they won't leave. Management also wastes money on "video game nights" so zero holiday bonus like a respectable company gives.. Rocket center is a revolving door and about a 50% or more turn around rate, employees never stay because the paid is band 4 and they have you listed as band 11 and you work 80hrs and every single holiday, 7 days a week. They do no look into why a project was lost, its your fault and you will be punished. You feel like a slave and you can't stand up for yourself because you fear losing your job, its yes Master and thats it. Salary is modern salvery. I could go on but read the rest of the reviews... nothing has changed in the last 3+ years.

review_title: WORST. ABSOLUTELY WORST. DO NOT JOIN.
pros: Wfh. Flexible Timings. No formal clothes.
